Out of curiosity, and to spark debate,

how can this (below) be expanded to=
 include the general case of a
generalized device that is capable of 'learn=
ing' and developing it's
own strategy?  That is, it 'learns' the rules, it =
develops a strategy,
and some of what is 'learned' in one game is transferr=
able to another
game.

Or is that not the ultimate goal?

What if you were =
to attempt to evolve a network that is capable of
playing 10 different game=
s?  Chess.  Checkers, Go, tic-tac-toe, and
who knows how many others.  The =
search space would be impossibly
large, and perhaps even impossible to trav=
erse.  The only possible
solution would be a generalized learning mechanism=
, wouldn't it?  But
would we ever find it?

On 9/30/05, Derek James <djames=
@...> wrote:
> On 9/28/05, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote:=

> >
> > When we say "let's evolve a player for game X" we are actually bei=
ng
> > ambiguous.
>
> Exactly...which is why I would personally shy away fr=
om using such
> words as "optimal" or "perfect" for evolved strategies or p=
layers.
>
> > We might mean:
> >
> > - evolve a player in the context of so=
me opponent(s), or,
> > - evolve a fixed strategy for the general case of a=
ny opponent, or,
> > - evolve a adaptive strategy that adjusts itself to th=
e current opponent
> >
> > At the moment I am working on the second of thes=
e, and I'll use a lot of
> > instances of the first along the way.  But I t=
hink the third is too far
> > beyond the current state of the art.
>
> Well=
 actually I don't think #3 is beyond the current state of the art,
> and sh=
ould be a working goal.  Hearing a talk on neural network
> ensembles at th=
is year's GECCO, though related to a control task, I
> could see how it cou=
ld easily be mapped onto a game domain.  If you
> evolve a number of differ=
ent "specialists", and then in a secondary
> phase, evolve a "coach" (calle=
d a "gating network" in Pardoe's paper)
> which decides at a given point in=
 time which of the specialists should
> be making the current move, you can=
 have adaptive behavior even
> without plasticity in the connection weights=
.  This approach would
> work better in longer games, or in the case of Tic=
-Tac-Toe or
> Roshambo, iterated games, which would give the coach network =
ample
> time to assess patterns in game play of the opponent.
>
> Derek
